Isn't that handled by the assig=
nment of number of offspring to a
species?  If species X is sceduled for ex=
tinction, then the number of
offspring that it is allowed to have in the ne=
xt generation is a
specific number.  Of course, if the mating of two others=
 result in
creating an offspring that should rightly be in species X, then =
so be
it.  But the longer species X goes without improvement, the bigger it=
s
penalty, the fewer offspring it can have.  The fewer offspring it can
hav=
e, the less likely its individuals will reproduce.  Over time, the
species =
is penalized out of existence.  If it comes back because of
happenstance, t=
hat's okay.

But that presumes that reproduction is on a species by species=
 basis. 
That is, species X has a fitness of N that is adjusted by the
popu=
lation size and the time since last improvement.  Based on
calculations, it=
 is determined that the species should have P
offspring in the next generat=
ion.  So, you generate 1 or 2 through
elitism, some percentage through weig=
ht mutation, and the rest through
crossover, with a percentage of those bei=
ng to an extra-species mate. 
Every offspring that is NOT due to crossover =
with an extra-species
mate is guaranteed to be in the same species as it wa=
s before, is it
not?

If those offspring created through extra-species mati=
ng should be in a
new species, so be it.  The question of species is one of=
 how much
diversity of structure is still close enough to be similar?  The
=
number of species then really just controls who mates with whom.  But
isn't=
 that a bit of a backwards and/or arbitrary way of doing so?

It would be a=
 pain in the butt, computationally speaking, but perhaps
the decision of wh=
o should reproduce with who should be determined
through some algorithm.  S=
ome genetic similarity metric (much like the
species control is now) couple=
d with a social status metric (fitness).
 A mating 'ritual' (algorithm) all=
ows them to pair up based on 'best
match' with some inherent flexibility to=
 allow for search space
flexibility. Then instead of keeping a number of sp=
ecies, and worrying
about how many there are, you simply forgoe the 'specie=
s' metric, and
adjust the mating algorithm so that it maintains genetic div=
ersity.

First, track each distinct topology.  Each time a new topology is
=
created, calculate its difference to every other topology that
currently ex=
ists in the population.  If a topology disappears and
re-appears, then you =
still have the difference metric to those that
were processed before, so yo=
u only have to recalculate it for those
topologies that appeared while that=
 topology was not present in the
population.

Then, devise a simple formula=
 that combines the topology difference
metric with the difference in fitnes=
s metric.  Bias it so that it
always tries to seek someone close to themsel=
ves, but better than
themselves.  For each individual, create a list of who=
 they would most
like to mate with.

Then go through and assign pairs.  For=
 the sake of argument, no
individual can mate more than once (or maybe twic=
e?).  Once you have a
list of pairs, decide which pairs to breed based on t=
he idea of
maintaining genetic diversity.

It's just an idea.  I'm not sure=
 if it has any benefits over the

lear idea of how it might be
